awd_titl_txt: Scripps Institution of Oceanography - Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to replace the currently used line-spoolers with actual certified winches has been a pressing need in the fleet for years. The line spoolers which are utilized throughout the fleet for mooring deployment and recovery efforts were never intended for use at sea, so it should come as no surprise these line spoolers haven?t proven themselves very sea-worthy. Line spoolers are portable winch-like machines designed for stringing and tensioning electric transmission lines on land. They are not compliant with both UNOLS RVSS Appendix B and 46 CFR. They are inexpensive, however, and have been supported through both the East and West Coast Winch Pools. The fleet urgently needs to begin replacing its line spoolers with mooring winches to meet safety standards and regulatory requirements, and to fully and reliably support field research projects carried out with moorings.   

A similar proposal was reviewed in panel from BIOS as they have begun to support increasing amounts of mooring work. The Program has decided to begin this transition to actual mooring winches over the next two years. A group purchase will be recommended to purchase five winches over two years. Although the WCWP proposal specified a "Markey" winch, after discussions with the institution, they are satisfied that all winches could be bought from the same manufacturer and that the volume discount will make them more affordable. The WCWP will be responsible for working with Hawboldt, the manufacturer, and BIOS, as well as the ECWP to spec the correct winch(s). The WCWP will take title to the equipment so if the vessel is retired or repurposed, the winches will return to the pool. All costs, including shipping, cables, commissioning, and attendance at the factory acceptance trials for the five winches are covered in this two-year award. Year one will constitute the down payment to beginning construction of the winches and the balance will be released in year two after an annual report documents that the work is complete.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advanced oceanographic winches for the NSF Oceanographic Winch Pools

The NSF West Coast Winch Pool (WCWP), managed by the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, manages, maintains, and operates a pool of portable winches and winch systems for shared use aboard oceanographic research vessels within the US Academic Research Fleet.  This equipment facilitates field operations and data collection on a range of oceanographic and survey vessels.  The primary beneficiaries of this pooled equipment are NSF-sponsored scientists, engineers, technicians and students.  Other beneficiaries are scientists sponsored by other federal agencies or research institutions (for example ONR, NOAA and others).  The WCWP has a proven track record of maintaining equipment in a “mission ready” status and delivering reliable equipment on time to projects around the world. 

The NSF East Coast Winch Pool (ECWP), managed by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), similarly manages, maintains, and operates a pool of portable winches and winch systems for shared-use.  Both Pools strive to identify and anticipate user/client equipment needs in order to procure and maintain inventories that will result in high utilization rates. Over time, maintenance costs of older equipment rise, machinery wears out, and technology and safety standards change.  The prudent operator monitors all of these factors and, when necessary, takes steps to replace older machinery with new machinery to ensure ongoing mission capability and success.  From time to time, the replacement needs of two or more operating entities overlap or converge.  When this happens, it makes sense for these entities to collaborate on group purchase proposals in order to take advantage of volume discounts offered by vendors. 

This award supported Scripps Institution of Oceanography to purchase a group of five modern oceanographic winches for distribution to the West Coast Winch Pool (WCWP), operated by Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO), the East Coast Winch Pool (ECWP), operated by Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, and R/V Atlantic Explorer, operated the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS).

Intellectual Merit

The observation, measurement, and collection of samples and data are accomplished on a global scale by operations aboard oceanographic research vessels. SIO-operated ships have played a critical role in the exploration of our planet since 1907 and, continue to contribute significantly to the U.S. ocean research effort. Shared-use instrumentation supported by the NSF and managed by institutions such as Scripps has historically enabled reliable, high-quality scientific measurements and observations to be conducted at sea in a flexible, efficient manner.

The oceanographic equipment requested here extends the NSF's ability to support transformative scientific research in physical and biological processes in the natural environment upon which human well-being depends. The equipment we acquired, tested and integrated into the US Academic Research Fleet replaced similar but obsolete equipment that SIO, WHOI, and BIOS had successfully operated and maintained for many years. SIO employed the resources of skilled technicians, tools, technical documentation and repair facilities that were used in the testing, calibration, sea trials and implementation of all of the proposed equipment. The knowledge, skill and abilities of SIO technical staff enabled these winches to be quickly established into productive service for the benefit of the broad scientific community.

Broader Impacts

The equipment acquired under this award contributes to the collaborative, multi-disciplinary and multi-institutional use of shared-use research and education infrastructure. As a charter member of UNOLS, SIO is actively involved in coordinating research vessel operations with scientists and funding agencies so that shipboard capabilities can best meet the current and anticipated research needs of the entire community. As a shared-use resource for NSF-supported scientists, the oceanographic winches procured under this award are now contributing to the education, training and outreach missions of all of the scientists (and their home institutions) who use them. As a result, the spectrum of research projects enabled by SIO’s management of shared-use oceanographic instrumentation achieves far-reaching broader impacts through the operation and maintenance of infrastructure that is critical to the promotion of training and learning, increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in research, advancing scientific and technological understanding and informing policy making.

The equipment awarded here directly supports NSF's mission. It also leverages institutional programs that indirectly advance NSF’s mission to promote achievement and progress in science, engineering and education for the benefit of the nation. In the five-year period ending in 2018, 1,029 graduate students, 747 undergraduate students, and 18 K-12 and undergraduate educators obtained first-hand experience at sea aboard SIO-operated research vessels. SIO-operated ships participate in SIO's UC Ship Funds Program, which enables graduate and undergraduate students, postdoctoral researchers and early career faculty to pursue independent research and instruction at sea via an internal peer-reviewed competitive process.
